p: Many countries have systematically increased the role of pharmacists in health care. Given the growing costs of health care resulting from the ageing of the population, the extension of life expectancy associated with the increase in the incidence of chronic diseases (e.g., diabetes, COPD) or the shortage of healthcare professionals, the potential of pharmacists is more fully used. Although the main task of pharmacists is to dispense drugs in public pharmacies, they also increasingly provide direct care for patients (e.g., vaccinations, monitoring clinical parameters, support in compliance with medical recommendations [ 37]. In the years 2000–2015, the number of pharmacists in the OECD nations group increased by 30% [ 13, 19]. The activation of this group increases the number of personnel involved in health care, improve patient’s care, and brings enormous savings.
